metadata.h1: Introduction to Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Bias in AI

all_paragraphs: Natural language processing (NLP) is a field that is being revolutionized by deep learning. From voice assistants to Gmail’s Smart Compose, deep learning has made it possible for machines to understand us in a more intuitive way.
Of course, working with natural data is very different than working with tabular data, because we now need to represent words and sentences in a way that machines can understand.
In this post, I will introduce key concepts of NLP such as word embeddings, and we will see how an algorithm can become biased, and how we can remove that bias.
For hands-on video tutorials on machine learning, deep learning, and artificial intelligence, checkout my YouTube channel.

Usually, when working with NLP applications, we access a dictionary of words, that contains thousands of different words. Now, we need to express each word in a way that a neural network can understand.

Using one-hot encoding is a common way to represent a word in a dictionary. For example, if you have a dictionary of 10 000 words, and “King” is the 4914th word, then its one-hot vector representation will be a 10000x1 vector filled with 0, but a 1 at position 4914.

The weakness of this representation is that it treats each word as a unique element by itself. This means that it will not recognize that both apple and orange are fruits, or that king and queen are related words. Therefore, it does not allow the algorithm to easily generalize the meaning of the words.

Assuming that you have basic knowledge of linear algebra, you realize that the dot product between any two vectors presented above will be 0! Therefore, there is no way for the algorithm to understand that certain words are related.
Instead of one-hot vectors, it would be useful to have words being represented as a collection of features. For example, there could be a “gender” feature, “food” feature, “age” feature, etc.
This forms the basis of word embedding. This allows to build matrix that lays out the different words, with a corresponding score for each feature.
This way, each word is now a vector where each value is a score for a certain feature.

From the picture above, let’s consider “Monarch” and “King”. Their respective vector is [0.5, 0.5, 1] and [0, 0, 1]. Now, we know that these words are related, and the dot product between both vectors is no longer 0! Thus, the algorithm can now understand that “Monarch” and “King” are related, just like “Monarch” and “Man” are not related.
We can further simplify this representation using t-SNE, and reducing the dimension space to 2D.
As you can see, similar words are grouped together, which show the advantage of using word embedding.

In this post, you learned how words are represented in natural language processing, you learned how to build a simple algorithm that can perform word analogy, and you saw how to remove gender bias in the algorithm.
Bias in AI algorithm can sometimes be a big problem, and the community is becoming increasingly aware of it. Be careful when you develop an algorithm and make sure it is as neutral as possible.
